variant.question: The 'Estimated Total Time' in block 16 of a VFR flight plan is the estimated time

options.text: required by the aircraft from take-off to arrive overhead the destination airport.
required by the aircraft from the moment it moves by its own power until it stops at the end of the flight (block time).
required by the aircraft from brake release at take-off until landing.
of endurance at cruising power taking into account pressure and temperature on that day.

options.text: Turn to heading 180º and descend to 2 300 ft.
Maintain current heading and call ATC because 2 300 ft is below MSA.
Turn to heading 180º, descend to 2 500 ft and call ATC because 2 300 ft is below MSA.
Turn to heading 180º, maintain current altitude, and call ATC because 2 300 ft is below MSA.

back to the departure aerodrome as the planned flight time taken to fly to it.

to the destination aerodrome as the flight planned time to the destination alternate.

Your estimated time over (ETO) a waypoint is **1443**, but ATC has cleared you at **1446**. Having settled on a suitably reduced speed, how can you check the validity of your calculation on the FMS?

options.text: The FMS will give you a new ETO which you compare against the ATC clearance.
The FMS gives you a new speed and distance which you can use to calculate the ETO.
The FMS gives you a new transit time for the leg, which you can use to calculate the ETO.
The FMS gives you only a speed, which you can use to calculate the ETO.
